required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Trial to Confirm the Clinical Efficacy and Safety of Dasiglucagon in the Treatment of Hypoglycemia in Subjects With T1DM
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Parallel-group Trial to Confirm the Clinical Efficacy and Safety of Dasiglucagon in the Rescue Treatment of Hypoglycemia in Subjects With Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) Compared to Placebo

brief_summary.textblock: A randomized, double-blind, parallel-group trial to confirm the clinical efficacy and safety of dasiglucagon in the rescue treatment of hypoglycemia in subjects with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) compared to placebo

detailed_description.textblock: Subjects were randomized in a ratio of 3:1 to receive a single subcutaneous dose of dasiglucagon (0.6 mg) or matching placebo. Randomization also determined whether the subject was to be injected in the buttock or deltoid. During the dosing visit (Visit 2), hypoglycemia was induced by a fast-acting insulin glulisine (Apidra®) infusion, and trial drug was administered when the subject's plasma glucose level was 45-60 mg/dL (2.5-3.3 mmol/L). During the insulin-induced hypoglycemia, pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic samples were drawn, and plasma glucose levels were monitored closely at site for safety reasons. A rescue glucose infusion could be administered to ameliorate persistent hypoglycemia. Subjects were followed for at least 28 days after dosing to perform an adequate immunogenicity evaluation of treatment.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Plasma glucose recovery was defined as first increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L) from baseline during the hypoglycemic clamp procedure without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose. Patients who received rescue IV glucose before 45 minutes and patients not recovering within 45 minutes after dosing were censored at 45 minutes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Plasma Glucose Recovery After Trial Drug Injection
secondary_outcome.description: Plasma glucose recovery (patient has achieved increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L)) within 30 minutes, within 20 minutes, within 15 minutes, and within 10 minutes after trial drug injection without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose.
Plasma glucose changes from baseline at 30 minutes, at 20 minutes, at 15 minutes, and at 10 minutes after trial drug injection or at the time of rescue (patient level).

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Target Plasma Glucose Concentration
secondary_outcome.description: Time to first plasma glucose concentration ≥70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) without administration of rescue intravenous glucose

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacodynamics - Area Under the Effect Curve
secondary_outcome.description: Plasma glucose response as area under the effect curve (AUE) above baseline from time zero to 30 minutes, AUE0-30min.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacokinetics - Area Under the Plasma Concentration Curve
secondary_outcome.description: Area under the drug concentration curve (AUC) from time zero to 90 minutes, AUC0-90min

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacokinetics - Area Under the Plasma Concentration Curve
secondary_outcome.description: Area under the drug concentration curve (AUC) from time zero to 120 minutes, AUC0-120min

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacokinetics - Time to Maximum Plasma Concentration
secondary_outcome.description: Time to maximum plasma dasiglucagon concentration (tmax)
Occurrence of antibodies against dasiglucagon. Presented as percentage of patients with antibodies.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rescue Infusions of IV Glucose After Trial Drug Administration
secondary_outcome.description: Presented as number of patients with rescue infusions of IV glucose after trial drug administration. This was a safety outcome measure. IV = intravenous

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Rescue Infusion of IV Glucose After Trial Drug Administration
secondary_outcome.description: Safety outcome measure: time to first rescue infusion of IV glucose after trial drug administration. IV = intravenous

arm_group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of dasiglucagon
single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of placebo

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female or male subjects with T1DM for at least 1 year; diagnostic criteria as defined by the American Diabetes Association (3).
- Treated with insulin for T1DM for at least 1 year and with stable insulin treatment (defined as no more than a 10-unit daily variation in total daily insulin dose) 30 days prior to screening
- Hemoglobin A1c <10%.
- Aged between 18 and 75 years, both inclusive.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous participation in a clinical trial within the dasiglucagon in the rescue treatment of hypoglycemia program.
- Known or suspected allergy to trial drug(s) or related products.
- History of anaphylaxis or symptoms of severe systemic allergy (such as angioedema).
- Previous participation in this trial. Participation being defined by signing the informed consent document.

outcome.title: Time to Plasma Glucose Recovery.
outcome.description: Plasma glucose recovery was defined as first increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L) from baseline during the hypoglycemic clamp procedure without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose. Patients who received rescue IV glucose before 45 minutes and patients not recovering within 45 minutes after dosing were censored at 45 minutes.
outcome.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

measure.title: Time to Plasma Glucose Recovery.
measure.description: Plasma glucose recovery was defined as first increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L) from baseline during the hypoglycemic clamp procedure without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose. Patients who received rescue IV glucose before 45 minutes and patients not recovering within 45 minutes after dosing were censored at 45 minutes.
measure.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

measurement_list.measurement: The upper limit was not estimable due to insufficient number of participants reaching recovery

analysis.groups_desc: The recovery rates of dasiglucagon and placebo were evaluated using a Kaplan Meier (KM) approach, with treatment group as a stratification factor. Differences between the KM curves (dasiglucagon versus placebo) were evaluated inferentially using pairwise two-sided log-rank tests stratified by injection site.

outcome.title: Plasma Glucose Recovery After Trial Drug Injection
outcome.description: Plasma glucose recovery (patient has achieved increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L)) within 30 minutes, within 20 minutes, within 15 minutes, and within 10 minutes after trial drug injection without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose.
outcome.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

group.title: Dasiglucagon 0.6 mg
group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of dasiglucagon Dasiglucagon: Glucagon analogue

measure.title: Plasma Glucose Recovery After Trial Drug Injection
measure.description: Plasma glucose recovery (patient has achieved increase in plasma glucose of ≥20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L)) within 30 minutes, within 20 minutes, within 15 minutes, and within 10 minutes after trial drug injection without administration of rescue intravenous (IV) glucose.
measure.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

analysis.groups_desc: Assessed at 30 minutes. The recovery rates of dasiglucagon and placebo were compared at each time point using a Fisher's exact test. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Assessed at 20 minutes. The recovery rates of dasiglucagon and placebo were compared at each time point using a Fisher's exact test. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Assessed at 15 minutes. The recovery rates of dasiglucagon and placebo were compared at each time point using a Fisher's exact test. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Assessed at 10 minutes. The recovery rates of dasiglucagon and placebo were compared at each time point using a Fisher's exact test. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

outcome.title: Plasma Glucose Changes From Baseline
outcome.description: Plasma glucose changes from baseline at 30 minutes, at 20 minutes, at 15 minutes, and at 10 minutes after trial drug injection or at the time of rescue (patient level).
outcome.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of dasiglucagon Dasiglucagon: Glucagon analogue

group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of placebo Placebo: Placebo for dasiglucagon

measure.title: Plasma Glucose Changes From Baseline
measure.description: Plasma glucose changes from baseline at 30 minutes, at 20 minutes, at 15 minutes, and at 10 minutes after trial drug injection or at the time of rescue (patient level).
measure.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

analysis.groups_desc: Change from baseline in plasma glucose at 30 minutes after investigational product injection was calculated using nominal sampling times and analyzed using an analysis of variance model with treatment, age group and injection site for each endpoint. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Change from baseline in plasma glucose at 20 minutes after investigational product injection was calculated using nominal sampling times and analyzed using an analysis of variance model with treatment, age group and injection site for each endpoint. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Change from baseline in plasma glucose at 15 minutes after investigational product injection was calculated using nominal sampling times and analyzed using an analysis of variance model with treatment, age group and injection site for each endpoint. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

Change from baseline in plasma glucose at 10 minutes after investigational product injection was calculated using nominal sampling times and analyzed using an analysis of variance model with treatment, age group and injection site for each endpoint. Testing followed an a priori defined hierarchical inferential test order, proceeding until the first failure to reject the null hypothesis comparing dasiglucagon versus placebo.

outcome.title: Time to Target Plasma Glucose Concentration
outcome.description: Time to first plasma glucose concentration ≥70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) without administration of rescue intravenous glucose
outcome.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

group.title: Dasiglucagon 0.6 mg
group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of dasiglucagon Dasiglucagon: Glucagon analogue

group.title: Placebo
group.description: single fixed dose (subcutaneous injection) of placebo Placebo: Placebo for dasiglucagon

measure.title: Time to Target Plasma Glucose Concentration
measure.description: Time to first plasma glucose concentration ≥70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) without administration of rescue intravenous glucose
measure.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

analysis.groups_desc: Evaluated using a Kaplan Meier (KM) approach, with treatment group as a stratification factor, analogous to that used for the primary endpoint analysis. Differences between the KM curves (dasiglucagon versus placebo) were evaluated inferentially using pairwise two-sided log-rank tests. Subjects whose time to first plasma glucose concentration ≥70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) was not met within 45 minutes post-dosing were censored, at the time of the last valid plasma glucose measurement up to 45 minutes.

outcome.title: Pharmacodynamics - Area Under the Effect Curve
outcome.description: Plasma glucose response as area under the effect curve (AUE) above baseline from time zero to 30 minutes, AUE0-30min.
outcome.population: The full analysis set of all randomized subjects who received at least one dose of trial drug (same as the safety analysis set)

analysis.groups_desc: The analysis was an analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) model with treatment group as factor and the baseline of the dependent variable plasma glucose as a covariate.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
